references:
We empirically show how the noise scale for backdoor elimination changes after applying each step of FLAME.
Particularly, we measure the smallest Gaussian noise scale σ𝜎\sigma required to defeat all backdoors (i.e., B​A=0%𝐵𝐴percent0BA=0\%) in three settings: i) No defense components applied (which is equivalent to the previous DP-based defense [20, 9]); ii) After applying dynamic clustering;
iii) After applying both dynamic clustering and adaptive clipping (which is the setting of FLAME).
We conduct this comparison experiment on the IoT-Traffic dataset (cf. §6). For each communication round, 100 clients are selected where k=40𝑘40k=40 are adversaries. We remove the backdoor by adding Gaussian noise N​(0,σ2)𝑁0superscript𝜎2{N}(0,\sigma^{2}) to the aggregated model. Table 1 summarizes the evaluation results in the above three settings. We can observe from the comparison results that the noise scale required to eliminate backdoors decreases after individual deployment of clustering and clipping.
This corroborates the correctness of Theorem 2.

𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} can add noise to the poisoned models to make them difficult to detect. However, our evaluation of such an attack on the IoT-Traffic dataset shows that this strategy is not effective.
We evaluate different noise levels to determine a suitable standard deviation for the noise. Thereby, we observe that a noise level of 0.0340.0340.034 causes the models’ cosine distances in clustering to change without significantly impacting 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA}. However, FLAME can still efficiently defend this attack: 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA} remains at 0%percent00\% and 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} at 100%.

We extend our evaluation to various backdoors on three datasets. For NIDS, we evaluate 13 different backdoors (Mirai malware attacks) and 24 device types (78 IoT devices). The results show that FLAME is able to mitigate all backdoor attacks completely while achieving a high MA=99.8%. We evaluate 5 different word backdoors for WP, and 90 different image backdoors for IC, which change the output of a whole class to another class. In all cases,

) but fail to remove a sufficient number of poisoned updates, these defenses increase the

Using the same attack parameter values, i.e.,

), for all malicious clients can result in high distances between benign and poisoned models. Those high distances can be illustrated as a gap between poisoned and benign models, s.t. the clustering can separate them. Therefore, a sophisticated adversary can generate models that bridge the gap between them such that they are merged to the same cluster in our clustering. We evaluate this attack on the IoT-Traffic dataset for

). This can be explained by the fact that when the adversary
tunes malicious updates to be close to the benign ones, the attack’s impact is reduced and consequently averaged out by our noising component.

references: paper at the USENIX Security Conference in 2022
, it has sparked considerable interest among researchers, garnering over 100 citations according to Google Scholar
. When creating this document, two attacks have been highlighted that allege to circumvent
. We promptly responded by conducting an exhaustive investigation into these attacks, uncovering notable errors in their approach. They made misleading claims and seemed to misinterpret
’s core design principles. To resolve this issue, we initiated a dialogue with the respective authors, leading to an acknowledgment and ensuing correction of assertions by Xu et al.
. In the subsequent sections, we explore these studies in greater detail.
propose a distributed backdoor attack (DBA) targeting federated Graph Neural Networks (GNN) training. The authors assert their proposed attacks can circumvent
. However, upon discussing this with the authors of
, it becomes clear that they have misinterpreted our approach and failed to incorporate all key components of
in their understanding. Specifically, they have only accounted for the clustering aspect of

while neglecting the Adaptive Clipping and Noising components, both of which are essential for backdoor mitigation. Acknowledging this, the authors have revised their claim in the recent version of their paper published on arXiv
introduce 3DFed , a multifaceted backdoor attack composed of three elements: Constrain Loss, Noise Masks, and Decoy Model. Among these, the Constrain Loss component is crafted to target
. However, it solely aims to counteract the Clipping defense facet of

. This implies that the authors did not account for the Clustering and Noising elements intrinsic to our defense design. At its core, 3DFed  seeks to limit the loss during the backdoor model training phase, striving to keep the backdoor objective closely aligned with the global model in terms of
(Euclidean distance). This alignment is achieved by manipulating the hyper-parameter
, meaning 3DFed ’s goal is to ensure the
of the backdoor model falls under the
, however, the authors neither discuss nor assess how hyper-parameter
s of backdoored models fall below our dynamic Clipping boundary. It is important to note that because the Clipping threshold in
is dynamically recalculated with each federated training iteration, it’s highly unlikely that a particular

s of tampered models stay below our dynamic Clipping threshold while still maintaining the attack’s effectiveness. This is particularly true once Gaussian noise is factored in. As we highlighted in Section
, we are aware of such tampered models, working on the assumption that an adversary can carefully manipulate the training process (see Constrain-and-scale attack

).
Consequently, we argue that 3DFed  cannot counteract
. To empirically support this argument, we have carried out a comprehensive replication study of 3DFed  using the exact source code provided by the 3DFed  authors
, strictly adhering to the experimental setup detailed in the 3DFed paper
. As anticipated, contrary to the results presented in the 3DFed  paper, specifically Figures 10c, 10h, and 13c
’s effective mitigation of 3DFed attacks across all datasets used in 3DFed  experiments (see Table
underscores the significant discrepancy between how recent attacks interpret
and the actual design principles of

. Importantly, none of these approaches consider the Adaptive Noising defense, which plays a crucial role in eliminating remaining backdoor updates. This highlights the essentiality of comprehending design principles when devising an attack against

references: For our implementation, we use the STPC framework ABY
which implements the three sharing types, including state-of-the-art optimizations and flexible conversions and the open-source privacy-preserving DBSCAN by Bozdemir et al.
. All STPC results are averaged over 10 experiments and run on two separate servers with Intel Core i9-7960X CPUs with 2.8 GHz and 128 GB RAM connected over a 10 Gbit/s LAN with 0.2 ms RTT.
We measure the effect of approximating
including the binary search for the neighborhood parameter

. The results show that our approximation has a negligible loss of accuracy. For some applications, the approximation
even performs slightly better than the standard
correctly filters all poisoned models, while standard
), which is still sufficient to achieve
We evaluate the runtime in seconds per training iteration of the cosine distance, Euclidean distance + clipping + model aggregation, and clustering steps of Alg.
in standard (without STPC) and in private
(with STPC). The results show that private
causes a significant overhead on the runtime by a factor of up to three orders of magnitude compared to the standard (non-private)
. However, even if we consider the largest model (Reddit) with
clients, we have a total server-side runtime of 22 081.65 seconds (
6 hours) for a training iteration with STPC. Such runtime overhead would be acceptable to maintain privacy, especially since mobile phones, which would be a typical type of clients in FL

, are not always available and connected so that there will be delays in synchronizing clients’ model updates in FL. These delays can then also be used to run STPC. Furthermore, achieving provable privacy by using STPC may even motivate more clients to contribute to FL in the first place and provide more data.
